On 12/3/05, Ramin Lessani <kcy42rl@...> wrote:
>
> I want to =
use NEAT for a board game (hex)to train neural network
> controlled roving =
eye. if any one can suggest how i can use ANJI "Roving
> eye" part . I will=
 be ever so  grateful or any  suggestions would be
> highly appreciated.

H=
i Ramen,

If you haven't already, I'd suggest reading Ken's paper "Evolving=
 a
Roving Eye for Go"

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?stanley:gecco04

as =
well as our paper "Evolving a Neural Network Active Vision System
for Shape=
 Discrimination".  The first describes Ken's approach to
applying a roving =
eye paradigm to small-board Go and scaling up to
slightly larger boards.  T=
he second describes how our version of the
roving (or "floating") eye is im=
plemented, at a fairly high level of
description.

Then you might want to p=
oke around the code.  Here are the ANJI javadocs:

http://anji.sourceforge.=
net/javadoc/index.html

All the stuff that handles the eye is in the com.an=
ji.floatingeye
package.  Logic for playing ANNs against each other or again=
st
hand-coded algorithms is in com.anji.tournament, and logic specific to
T=
ic-Tac-Toe is in com.anji.ttt.

We implemented the floating eye for scannin=
g any 2D surface, but have
not yet applied it specifically to board games, =
although I'm going to
try to implement this for 9x9 Go next semester for my=
 first-year
project, so please let me know how you're progressing.  Carryin=
g on
the discussion through the list is probably a good idea, so that
other=
s who might be working on similar issues can chime in or simply
reference t=
he thread.

Derek
